question: What are you trying to show?

options.question: How many categories are you comparing?
What's the nature of the comparison?

options.description: Use a bar chart for raw values. Consider horizontal orientation if labels are long. Add data labels if exact values are important.
Use a horizontal bar chart, sorted by value. Works best for up to 20-25 items. For more, consider filtering, grouping, or showing top N.
Use a bar chart with reference line or bullet chart. Consider color coding bars based on whether they exceed the benchmark.

options.question: Are the categories hierarchical (one contains the other)?
What type of comparison are you making?
How many items at each level?

options.description: Use grouped bars with drill-down capability. Show parent level first, allow drilling to child level comparisons.

options.question: Can the data be aggregated or filtered?

options.description: Use grouped bars with filters to limit visible items. Consider showing top N with option to see more.
Use a heatmap with hierarchical labels. Consider adding interactive tooltips for exact values.

options.question: How many components at child level?

options.description: Use stacked bars with drill-down. Color consistently across levels. Consider adding percentage labels.

options.question: Can small items be grouped?

options.description: Group smaller items into 'Other' category. Provide drill-down to see full breakdown.
Use treemap for many items. Add interactive tooltips and ensure color coding is meaningful.
Use small multiples showing parent level patterns, with drill-down to child level. Consider adding summary metrics.

options.question: What aspect are you comparing?
How many total combinations?

options.description: Use grouped bars. Consider sorting by total or one category. Add data labels if space permits.

options.question: Can data be aggregated?

options.description: Use heatmap with aggregated categories. Provide drill-down for details.
Use heatmap with scroll or filter controls. Consider showing top N by default.

options.question: Is one category more important?
How many components?

options.description: Use stacked bars. Order segments consistently. Consider adding percentage labels.

options.question: Can components be grouped?

options.description: Group smaller segments into 'Other'. Provide tooltip or details on demand.
Use heatmap showing distribution. Consider adding marginal distributions.

options.question: How many values in each category?

options.description: Use 100% stacked bars. Consider both vertical and horizontal orientations.
Use heatmap normalized within categories. Add tooltips for exact values.

options.question: What aspect of composition matters most?
How many components are you showing?
Are exact proportions important?

options.description: Use a 100% stacked bar chart. Add percentage labels. Consider horizontal orientation if labels are long. Works best when precise comparison is needed.
Use a pie chart for a quick visual share of the whole. Order slices by size. Add direct labels if space permits. Best when relative proportions matter more than exact values.

options.question: Can smaller components be grouped?

options.description: Use a pie chart with smaller segments grouped as 'Other'. Add tooltips or details-on-demand for grouped items. Consider showing top N plus Other.
Use a 100% stacked bar. Consider horizontal orientation for better label readability. Add interactive tooltips for smaller segments.

options.question: Is hierarchy present in the data?

options.description: Use a treemap to show nested composition. Color by hierarchy level or another meaningful metric. Add interactive tooltips and drill-down capability.

options.question: Is interaction possible?

options.description: Use a scrollable/filterable bar chart. Show top N by default with option to see more. Add search/filter capabilities for specific components.
Group into meaningful categories. Consider showing as 100% stacked bars with major categories only. Provide full breakdown in tooltip or separate view.

options.question: How many time periods?
How many components?

options.description: Use two pie charts side by side. Maintain consistent ordering and colors. Add delta indicators for significant changes.
Use side-by-side 100% stacked bars. Focus on major changes. Consider adding change indicators or delta chart.

options.question: How many components?

options.description: Use a 100% stacked area chart. Consider interactive tooltips for exact values. Add legend with toggles for focus.

options.question: Can components be grouped?

options.description: Group smaller components. Show major categories in stacked area chart. Provide drill-down for details.
Use small multiple area charts. Show one component per chart. Consider showing only key components with option to see others.

options.question: How many hierarchy levels?
How many items at each level?

options.description: Use a sunburst chart. Add interactive highlights for parent-child relationships. Consider adding breadcrumb navigation.
Use a treemap. Color by level or metric. Add interactive drill-down and tooltips. Consider showing only major categories by default.

options.question: Is interaction available?

options.description: Use an interactive treemap with drill-down. Start with top level, allow exploration. Add breadcrumb navigation and search.
Use nested bars showing 2-3 most important levels. Group minor categories. Provide separate detailed view if needed.

options.question: What aspect of the distribution are you focusing on?
Are you working with a small or large dataset?

options.description: Visualize how data is spread out across value ranges. For senior living, this could highlight distribution of resident ages or satisfaction scores.
considerations: For fewer data points, bins can be manually set to show meaningful groupings.
Consider interactive hover to see exact bin counts or percentages.

options.description: Allows panning or zooming to explore data distribution in detail. Useful for large sets like resident daily activity logs or thousands of service durations.
considerations: Use dynamic bin sizing or smoothing to manage large data volumes.
Add filters to focus on specific segments (e.g., by location or service type).

options.description: Highlight median, quartiles, and outliers. Good for seeing if certain facilities or service offerings deviate significantly from normal patterns.
considerations: Useful when comparing distributions across multiple groups (e.g., different facilities).
Consider grouping or coloring by categories (e.g., level of care) for clarity.

options.description: Displays distribution for each group, showing density as well as outliers. Great for in-depth comparisons among multiple categories, like comparing service usage across departments.
considerations: Might be too complex for quick snapshots; best used in exploratory dashboards.
Ensure labeling is clear so that stakeholders understand the shape and spread.

options.question: What type of relationship are you exploring?

options.description: Plot two measures to see if there's a relationship. For instance, visualize if resident satisfaction correlates with staffing hours.
considerations: Consider adding a trend line to highlight correlation.
Include tooltips or markers for outlier points of interest.

options.description: Show pairwise correlations across multiple metrics, such as occupancy rates, satisfaction scores, and operational costs.
considerations: Color coding helps quickly spot strong or weak correlations.
Interactive filtering can help isolate key metrics for deeper analysis.

options.description: Visualize complex relationships such as referral patterns between facilities or staff collaboration networks.
considerations: Node size or color can represent additional metrics (e.g., number of residents referred).
Ensure the diagram doesn’t become cluttered with large networks; consider grouping or clustering.

options.description: Compare multiple numeric variables in a grid of scatter plots, such as cost, care hours, and satisfaction.
considerations: Can be overwhelming with too many variables; choose key metrics.
Interactive brushing/highlighting can help identify patterns or clusters across multiple plots.

options.question: What is your main focus over time?
Is the dataset small (few data points) or large (frequent data)?

options.description: Ideal for monthly or quarterly data to track changes in one metric, such as average occupancy or average length of stay over time.
considerations: Highlight significant milestones or events (e.g., policy changes).
Add data labels for key points if clarity is needed.

options.description: Allows users to navigate dense time series data (e.g., daily or hourly staff hours) with zoom and filters.
considerations: Use tooltips on hover to get exact values for busy areas.
Consider resampling or aggregating data (weekly/monthly) to prevent clutter.

options.text: Multiple metrics or comparisons over time
options.question: How many metrics do you want to track simultaneously?

options.description: Compare up to three trends in one chart (e.g., occupancy rate vs. satisfaction vs. staffing).
considerations: Use consistent scales or dual axes only if absolutely necessary.
Add a clear legend or interactive toggles for metrics.

options.description: Place each metric in its own mini-chart for easier comparison (e.g., separate lines for each facility metric).
considerations: Allows a quick glance across multiple trends without overcrowding a single chart.
Use consistent scales across panels for straightforward comparison.

options.description: Visualize critical events or phases, like project milestones (new wing construction) or resident transitions (move-in vs. move-out dates).
considerations: Gantt charts help track tasks or phases with start/end dates.
Timelines are ideal for highlighting key milestones or changes in regulations.

options.question: What is your ranking focus?

options.description: Show items sorted by value, highlighting top or bottom performers. For example, ranking facilities by satisfaction scores or occupancy rates.
considerations: Use color or icons to highlight top/bottom categories.
For large lists, consider adding a search or filter function.

options.description: Perfect for quickly seeing how each item measures up to a benchmark (e.g., target occupancy or revenue).
considerations: Keep the design simple: show performance bar, target marker, and possibly qualitative ranges (e.g., poor, good, excellent).
Useful for monthly or quarterly performance dashboards.

options.description: If you have many items (e.g., 50+ staff members or residents), use an interactive table allowing sorting and filtering.
considerations: Enable column sorting and search to find specific items quickly.
Consider conditional formatting (e.g., highlight values above/below average).

options.question: What geographic aspect are you visualizing?
Are you focusing on differences by region?

options.text: Yes, I'd like to compare regions or states
options.description: Color-coded regions to show differences (e.g., state-level occupancy rates or market penetration).
considerations: Use a clear color scale to show high-to-low values.
For large datasets, consider simplifying boundaries or offering drill-down.

options.text: No, I'd like exact facility locations
options.description: Place markers on the map for each facility or relevant location. Marker size or color can represent key metrics (e.g., facility capacity).
considerations: Works best when points are not too dense. Otherwise, consider clustering or heatmaps.
Tooltips can show additional details on hover.

options.question: How many points or addresses are plotted?

options.description: Shows each facility or residence individually. Can highlight resident location clusters or specific properties.
considerations: Adding labels or pop-ups can provide extra details about each location.
Be mindful of privacy concerns when mapping exact addresses.

options.description: When many points overlap, clustering or a heatmap helps visualize densities (e.g., distribution of referrals or leads).
considerations: Allow zooming to see more granularity in areas with high point density.
Use color gradients or cluster icons to clarify data hotspots.
